unnormalised: The tailor, Ramlal ji, squinted at the measuring tape, his brow furrowed in concentration. He'd been a tailor in this small town for over 40 yrs, and in all that time, he'd learned that the difference between a satisfied customer and a disgruntled one often came down to a mere fraction of an inch, or rather, 0.1 cm. He took careful note of Mrs. Sharma's measurements, from her shoulder width of precisely 15 inches to the desired length of the saree blouse, 14.5 inches, not a millimeter more or less.

He took careful note of Missus Sharma's measurements, from her shoulder width of precisely fifteen inches to the desired length of the saree blouse, fourteen point five inches, not a millimeter more or less.

unnormalised: Mrs. Sharma, a regular customer, hovered anxiously nearby. "Ramlal ji," she fretted, "are you sure about the sleeves? I want them exactly 6 inches. Last time, they were a little too short."

unnormalised: Ramlal ji chuckled, a dry, rustling sound. "Madam, trust me. My tape doesn't lie. Six inches it shall be. And the 'ghera' (flare) of the lehenga? You wanted 2.5 meters, correct?" He made a note, double-checking the measurement on his worn, leather-bound notebook. Each garment, from the simplest kurta to the most elaborate wedding lehenga, was meticulously documented, a testament to his years of dedication.

unnormalised: He reminisced about his early days, when measurements were taken in 'haath' (cubits) and 'ungli' (finger widths), methods passed down through generations. It was a far cry from the modern measuring tapes that displayed figures in both inches and cm. Back then, a 'haath' was roughly 18 inches, but everyone had their own interpretation, leading to many amusing, and occasionally frustrating, tailoring mishaps.

unnormalised: The shop itself was a testament to time. The walls were lined with rolls of fabric, ranging from vibrant silks to sturdy cottons. A vintage sewing machine, a relic from his father's time, sat proudly in the corner. He still used it for certain tasks, preferring its reliable hum to the modern, computerized machines. He even kept a small box filled with old, tarnished weights, some measured in 'tola' (approx. 11.66 grams), a unit of weight once commonly used for measuring precious metals and spices.

unnormalised: "The 'pheti' (waistband) should be 32 inches, right?" Ramlal ji asked, interrupting Mrs. Sharma's reverie as she admired a particularly beautiful silk saree. He carefully marked the fabric with chalk, his hand steady and practiced. Each cut was precise, a testament to his years of experience. He knew that a perfectly tailored garment could make all the difference in a person's confidence and comfort.

unnormalised: He knew the younger generation preferred ready-made clothes, but he still had his loyal clientele. They appreciated the personalized touch, the meticulous attention to detail, and the assurance that their clothes would fit perfectly, down to the last 1/8 inch. Ramlal ji, the keeper of measurements, the guardian of perfectly fitted garments, continued his craft, one stitch, one measurement, one satisfied customer at a time. He carefully measured out 1 meter of 'astar' lining to complete the saree. He knew it would make all the difference.
